conclusion: Analysis of Object A's fall and collision path will be based on gravity, collision, and deflection effects observed in the scene.

In the first image, object A (the orange ball marked with a red arrow) is positioned above the rightmost yellow blocks and appears to be directly above or slightly to the right of the gap between the two yellow blocks.
Due to gravity, object A will fall vertically downward in a straight line from its starting position as it has no initial horizontal velocity component.

The primary collision targets for object A would be the two yellow blocks positioned directly below it, or it might hit just one block if it falls slightly to the side, or it might miss them entirely if it falls perfectly between the gap.
In the second image, the orange ball has come to rest between the two yellow blocks, appearing to have landed in the gap without significantly displacing them.

The ball fell largely through the gap between the yellow blocks, with any slight contact causing minor deflection, and its momentum was insufficient to significantly displace the blocks. The ball came to rest due to the table surface stopping its vertical motion.

Object A (the orange ball) will fall vertically downward due to gravity and will primarily fall through the gap between the two yellow blocks, making minimal or glancing contact with them. The final landing position is between the two yellow blocks on the green surface.
